$Takis Antoniou, "Epigrams". Translation: Theodore Sampson. _Greek Letters_ 24 (2011-2012): 247-252.

_Demetrios Capetanakis: A Greek Poet in England._ John Lehmann, intro. London: John Lehmann, 1947. vii, 183 p.

Published again in Freeport, N.Y.: Books for Libraries Press, 1971. vii, 183 p.

ISBN ---

This book contains all that he wrote in Englishduring his stay in England (among which 16 poems). Also contains essays about the poet: Edith Sitwell: "The Poetry of Demetrios Capetanakis" (pp. 35-41); Panayiotis Canellopoulos, "My Friend Demetrios Capetanakis" (pp. 173-175); William Plomer, "A Recollection" (pp. 181-183).

full_text:
**SAW** [C.P. Cavafy]. _Alternative Manners: Poems of C.P. Cavafy_. English versions by Desmond O'Grady. [s.l.]: [s.n.], 1993. 52 p.

ISBN ---

Contents: Desmond O'Grady, "Preface" (pp. 7-9); Acknowledgements (p. 10); "Cavafy in Alexandria" (from O'Grady's _Alexandria Notebook_) (p. 11). A selection of 33 poems:

"Candles" (p. 12); "Footsteps" (p. 13); "Ithaca" (pp. 14-16); "Voices" (p. 17); "The City" (p. 18); "Ionian" (p. 19); "Windows" (p. 20); "Waiting for the Barbarians" (pp. 21-22); "One of Their Gods" (p. 23); "Thermopylae" (p. 24); "Come Back" (p. 25); "I Went" (p. 26); "He Swears" (p. 27); "One Night" (p. 28); "The Tobacco Kiosk" (p. 29); "Days of 1903" (p. 30); "I've Seen So Much Beauty" (p. 31); "Rites of Passage" (p. 32); "Long Ago" (p. 33); "At the Café Door" (p. 34); "Nero's Hour" (p. 35); "One Evening" (p. 36); "Remember, Body" (p. 37); "In a Town of Osroini" (p. 38); "Grey" (p. 39); "The Month of Athyr" (p. 40); "Tomb of Iasis" (p. 41); "That House" (p. 42); "Since Nine O'Clock" (p. 43); "At Rest in Verse" (p. 44); "On Board Ship" (p. 45); "Those Who Fought for the Achaian League" (p. 46); "He Came to Read" (p. 47). Biographies (pp. 48-51).

[A different version of "Ionian" appeared as "My Country" in Desmond O'Grady's _His Skaldorane's Nest_, poems (Gallery Press, Dublin 1970). Slightly different versions of "One of their Gods", under the title of "One of Them", and "Waiting for the Barbarians" appeared in _The Writers, A Sense of Ireland_ (eds. Andrew Carpenter and Peter Fallon, Dublin 1980).]

Dia saw.

full_text:
[C.P. Cavafy]. _Before Time Could Change Them: The Complete Poems of Constantine P. Cavafy_. Translated, with an Introduction and Notes by Theoharis Constantine Theoharis. New York, San Diego, London: Harcourt, Inc.,2001. xxx, 354 p.

ISBN 0-15-100519-2 (hardback); 9780151005192

Gore Vidal, Foreword (pp. xv-xxi); Introduction: 'Let All Its Guarded Passion Shine' (pp. xxiii-xxx); "Poems: 1905-1915" (pp. 1-45); "Poems: 1916-1918" (pp. 47-77); "Poems: 1897-1908 excluded from 'Poems: 1905-1915' and 'Poems 1916-1918'" (pp. 79-99); "Unpublished Poems: 1919-1932" (pp. 101-184); "One Extra: 1933": "In the Districts Surrounding Antioch" (pp. 185-188); "Hidden Poems: 1884-1923" (pp. 189-275); "Prose Poems from _Hidden Poems_" (pp. 275-279); "Rejected Poems: 1886-1898" (pp. 281-319); Notes on Selected Poems (pp. 320-353).

From the introduction (p. xxix): "I have translated the standard texts of Cavafy's poems established by George Savidis: _Poems: Volume I (1897-1918), Volume II (1919-1933)_, Ikaros Press, Athens, 1991; _Hidden Poems (1877-1923)_, Ikaros Press, Athens, 1993; and _Rejected Poems_, Ikaros Press, Athens. 1983. I have not included the thirty fragments and sketches collecetd by R. Lavagnini in _C. P. Cavafy, Unfinished Poems 1918-1932_, Ikaros Press, Athens, 1994".

C.P. Cavafy. _Collected Poems._ Translated by Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard. Edited by George Savidis. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1974. xvii, 451 p. Bilingual edition.

ISBN 069106279X; 9780691062792

Contains: Translators' Foreword (pp. vii-viii); "Published Poems" (1896-1932) [153 poems] (pp. 1-333); "Unpublished Poems" (1896-1933) [22 poems] (pp. 335-385); Editor's Introduction (pp. 387-390); Appendix (pp. 391-392); Notes to the Poems (pp. 393-436); Biographical Note (pp. 437-441); Bibliographical Note (pp. 443-447); Alphabetical List of Titles (pp. 449-451).

Note: in the 1975 edition the poem "On the Outskirts of Antioch" (pp. 383-385) is included not with the Published Poems but with the Unpublished Poems (pace n. on p. 436).

6th printing with corrections, 1980; 3rd hardcover printing, with corrections, 1983.

Also \*London: The Hogarth Press, 1974.

With a new foreword by Robert Pinsky. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 2009. xxiv, 468 p. Bilingual edition.

ISBN 069114124X (pbk.); 9780691141244 (pbk.)

full_text:
[C.P. Cavafy]. _The Essential Cavafy_. Selected and with an Introduction by Edmund Keeley. Translated by Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard. Notes by George Savidis. The Essential Poets, 22. Hopewell, NJ: The Ecco Press, 1994. 69 p.

ISBN 0880014261; 9780880014267; 0-88001-516-0 pbk.

Introduction (pp. 3-18). Thirty-nine poems: "The Horses of Achilles" (p. 19); "Waiting for the Barbarians" (pp. 20-21); "Trojans" (pp. 21-22); "The City" (pp. 22-23); "The Satrapy" (p. 23) "The God Abandons Antony" (p. 24); "Ionic" (pp. 24-25); "Ithaka" (pp. 25-26); "Philhellene" (pp. 26-27); "Alexandrian Kings" (pp. 27-28); "He Swears" (p. 28); "For Ammonis, Who Died at 29, in 610" (p. 29); "One of Their Gods" (pp. 29-30); "In the Evening" (pp. 30-31); "Kaisarion" (pp. 31-32); "Nero's Deadline" (p. 32); "Since Nine O'Clock" (p. 33); "The Afternoon Sun" (pp. 33-34); "Comes to Rest" (pp. 34-35); "Dareios" (pp. 35-36); "A Byzantine Nobleman in Exile Composing Verses" (p. 37); "From the School of the Renowned Philosopher" (pp. 37-38); "In Despair" (p. 39); "John Kantakuzinos Triumphs" (pp. 39-40); "In a Township of Asia Minor" (pp. 40-41); "In the Tavernas" (p. 41); "Days of 1896" (p. 42); "In a Large Greek Colony, 200 B.C." (pp. 42-44); "A Prince from Western Libya" (pp. 44-45); "Myris: Alexandria, A.D. 340" (pp. 45-47); "To Have Taken the Trouble" (pp. 47-49); "In the Year 200 B.C." (pp. 49-50); "Days of 1908" (pp. 50-51); "Growing in Spirit" (pp. 51-52); "Going Back Home from Greece" (pp. 52-53); "Half an Hour" (p. 53); "The Bandaged Shoulder" (p. 54); "On the Outskirts of Antioch" (pp. 54-56); "The Ships" (pp. 56-58). Notes (pp. 59-68).

The prose poem "The Ships" (pp. 56-58) is an early "unpublished" poem (see note on p. 68: dated ca. 1895-96, and published by G.P. Savidis in 1986) translated by Edmund Keeley and Dimitri Gondicas and first published in _Antaeus_ 75/76 (Autumn 1994): 247-249.

Paperback ed. 1995

C P Cavafy]. Fourteen Poems by C P Cavafy, chosen and illustrated with twelve etchings by David Hockney. Translated by Nikos Stangos and Stephen Spender. London: Editions Alecto Limited, 1967. Limited edition. [39] p., [13] leaves of plates; oversize (48 cm.)

ISBN -----

Poems: "Caesarion"; "The Mirror at the Entrance"; "Two Boys Aged 23 or 24"; "He Enquired after the Quality"; "To Remain"; "According to Prescriptions of Ancient Magicians"; "In an Old Book"; "The Shop Window of a Tobacco Store"; "In the Dull Village"; "The Beginning"; "One Night"; "In Despair"; "Beautiful and White Flowers"; "Painted".

Etchings: "C P Cavafy in Alexandria"; "Two Boys Aged 23 or 24"; "He Enquired after the Quality"; "To Remain"; "According to Prescriptions of Ancient Magicians"; "In an Old Book"; "The Shop Window of a Tobacco Store"; "In the Dull Village"; "The Beginning"; "One Night"; "In Despair"; "Beautiful and White Flowers"; "Portrait of Cavafy II" (included loose in this edition).

The English translations of these poems are published by arrangement with Hogarth Press Limited, the publishers of _The Complete Poems of C P Cavafy_ translated by Rae Dalven.

The [interleaved] etchings have been hand printed from original copper plates 36 x 23 cm at the studios of Editions Alecto Limited, London.

Typography and book design by Gordon House.

Copy 71/500 (signed by the artist) in The Graphic Arts Collection, Rare Books and Special Collections, Princeton University Library.

full_text:
[C.P. Cavafy]. _Homage to Cavafy._ Ten Poems by Constantine Cavafy. Ten photographs by Duane Michals. Danbury, NH: Addison House, 1978. [48] p.

ISBN 0-89169-019-0; 9780891690191

The poems (which are numbered) are: 1. "Walls", 2. "He Swears", 3. "An Old Man", 4. "Prayer", 4. "The Bandaged Shoulder", 6. "Understanding", 7. "The Afternoon Sun", 8. "Longings", 9. "He Asked about the Quality", 10. "Half an Hour".

The poems are rendered in the translation of Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard.

full_text:
[C.P. Cavafy]. _Cavafy: 166 Poems_. Translated with an introduction by Alan L. Boegehold. Mount Jackson, VA: Axios Press, 2008. xx, 240 p.

ISBN 1604190051; 978-1-60419-005-2

Includes: Foreword by Peter Green (pp. xv-xvi); Introduction "Cavafy's Values" (pp. 1-28). The poems are the usual 154 of the canon + at the end, the following twelve from the 'Unpublished' and the 'Unfinished' ones: "At the Theater" (p. 227), "The Bandaged Shoulder" (p. 228), "Bank of the Future" (p. 229), "Attires" (p. 230), "The Death of the Emperor Tacitus" (p. 231), "Half Hour" (p. 232), "People of Poseidonia" (p. 233), "Return from Greece" (pp. 234-235), "The Saving of Julian" (unfinished) (p. 236), "Symeon" (pp. 237-238), "That Way" (p. 239), "The Rest I Shall Tell Them Below in the House of Hades" (p. 240).

C.P. Cavafy. _In Simple Clothes_. Etchings by William Brice. Translation by Alan Boegehold. Woodside, CA: Occasional Works, 1992. [6], 22, [2] p.

ISBN ---

Includes: "King Demetrios" (p. 3); "In Sparta" (p. 4); "Anna Dalassini" (p. 5); "Ithaca" (pp. 6-9); "In a Town of Asia Minor" (p. 10); "In the Month of Athyr" (p. 11); "Waiting for the Barbarians" (pp. 12-15); "Greek from Ancient Times" (p. 16); "Duke from Western Libya" (p. 16); "Steps" (pp. 18-20); "Alexandrian Kings" (pp. 21-22).

| Library Notes: On the verso of the "Contents" page a fragment of a few lines of the poem «Καισαρίων» (in Greek) and on the verso of the colophon its translation in English..Illustrations: 4 prints : etching, b&w ; full-page. From the colophon: "An edition limited to 65 copies, each containing four original etchings by William Brice."Copy 35 from the Graphic Arts Collection, Rare Books and Special Collections, Princeton University Library. |

Contains: Stavros Deligiorgis, Introduction (p. [5]; Twenty-one (mainly erotic) poems: "When They Stir in Your Mind" (p. [7]); "I've Gazed So Much" (p. [9]); "Very Seldom" (p. This selection of poems and illustrations was originally published in a German edition by Patrick Frey, Zürich, 1997.

C.P. Cavafy. _Morning Sea_ [a Poem]. Translated by John Mavrogordato. [London]: Burnt Wood Press, [1977].

"This poem by C P Cavafy was printed in an edition of twenty five in celebration of the silver jubilee year using lino and letter-press for the Burnt Wood Press." Signed by <the artist> Eileen Hogan 2/25/1977. (See entry #41 in Deree pamphlet on Cavafy). Title page plus eight pages of multi-colored letterpress with three pages of color illustrations, printed on Japanese handmade paper. (Fall colors used.)

Location: The American College of Greece; Rare Books and Special Collections.

C. P. Cavafy]. _Poems by C.P. Cavafy_. Translated, from the Greek, by J.C. Cavafy. With an introduction by Manuel Savidis. Athens: Ikaros, 2003. x, 82 p. <63 poems>

ISBN 960-7721-89-6 hbk.; 9789607721891 hbk.

Includes: Introduction (pp. ix-x). The Poems.

_First Book_: 1. "Voices" (p. 3); 2. "Longings" (p. 4); 3. "Candles" (p. 5); 4. "An Old Man" (p. 6); 4. "Supplication" (p. 7); 6. "The Souls of Old People" (p. 8); 7. "The First Rung" (p. 9); 8. "Interruption" (p. 10); 9. "Thermopylae" (p. 11); 10. "Che fece ... il gran rifiuto" (p. 12); 11. "The Windows" (p. 13); 12. "Trojans" (p. 14); 13. "Awaiting the Barbarians" (pp. 15-16); 14. "Monotony" (p. 17); 14. "Faithlessness" (pp. 18-19); 16. "The Funeral of Sarpedon" (pp. 20-21); 17. "The Horses of Achilles" (p. 22); 18. "The Company of Dionysos" (p. 23); 19. "King Demetrius" (p; 24); 20. "The Footfalls" (p. 25); 21. "'This Is He'" (p. 26); 22. "A Statuary of Tyana" (p. 27); 23. "Walls" (p. 28); 24. "Ended" (p. 29); 24. "The Place" (p. 30); 26. "The God Forsaketh Anthony" (p. 31); 27. "Satrapy" (p. 32); 28. "Ionic" (p. 33); 29. "Ides of March" (p. 34); 30. "Ithaca" (pp. 35-36); 31. "The Glory of the Ptolemies" (p. 37); 32. "The Perilous" (p. 38); 33. "Philhellene" (p. 39); 34. "Herodes Atticus" (p. 40); 34. "Come Again" (p. 41); 36. "In Church" (p. 42); 37. "All You Can" (p. 43); 38. "Of the Workshop" (p. 44); 39. "I Went" (p. 45); 40. "The Death of the Emperor Tacitus" (p. 46); 41. "In the Soul's House" (p. 47); 42. "Addition" (p. 48); 43. "The Intervention of the Gods" (p. 49); 44. "If Indeed He Died" (pp. 50-51).

_Second Book_: 44. "Manuel Comnenus" (p. 52); 46. "Very Seldom" (p. 53); 47. "Sea of the Morning" (p. 54); 48. "Pictured" (p. 55); 49. "Chandelier" (p. 56); 50. "Far Back" (p. 57); 51. "In a Town of Osrhöene" (p. 58); 52. "At the Café Door" (p. 59); 53. "Evening" (p. 60); 54. "One Night" (p. 61); 54. "Orophernes" (pp. 62-63); 56. "The Battle of Magnesia" (p. 64); 57. "Theodotus" (p. 65); 58. "The Vexation of the Seleucides" (pp. 66-67); 59. "Eurion's Grave" (p. 68); 60. "The Grave of Ignatius" (p. 69); 61. "Aemilian, the Son of Monaes, of Alexandria, 628-655 A.D." (p. 70); 62. "Alexandrian Kings" (pp. 71-72); 63. "The Grave of Lysias the Grammarian" (p. 73).

The Appendix, p. 77, includes the only known published translation of a poem by C. P. Cavafy signed by the author: "To Antiochus Epiphanes", translated by C.P. Cavafy, as published in the periodical _Échanges_ 5 (décembre 1931): 3.

N.B. Fifteen of John Cavafy's translations were published in the _St. Andrews Review_ 3.1 (Fall and Winter 1974): 37-47, with an introduction by Edmund Keeley (see no. 4.422).

[Constantine Cavafy]. _Poems of Constantine Cavafy._ Translated by George <Amin> Khairallah. Beirut: Heidelberg Press, 1979. 55 p.

ISBN ---

Contents: "Thermopylae" (p. 9); "Interruption" (p. 10); "Waiting for the Barbarians" (pp. 11-12); "King Demetrius" (p. 13); "The City" (p. 14); "The Satrapy" (p. 15); "The Ides of March" (p. 16); "Ionia" (p. 17); "The Glory of the Ptolemies" (p. 18); "Ithaca" (pp. 19-20); "Philhellene" (p. 21); "Alexandrian Kings" (pp. 22-23); "Rarely" (p. 24); "From the Shop" (p. 25); "Way Back" (p. 26); "The Morning Sea" (p. 27); "The Tomb of Iases" (p. 28); "At Evening" (p. 29); "Nero's Term" (p. 30); "The Next Table" (p. 31); "The Legates from Alexandria" (p. 32); "Here for Good" (p. 33); "Of Demetrius Soter (162-150 BC)" (pp. 34-35); "The Afternoon Sun" (p. 36); "Kindness of Alexander Balas" (p. 37); "The Maker of Kraters" (p. 38); "From the School of the Renowned Philosopher" (pp. 39-40); "On an Italian Shore" (p. 41); "The Illness of Kleitos" (p. 42); "In the Taverns" (p. 43); "Sophist Leaving Syria" (p. 44); "In a Town in Asia Minor" (p. 45); "He Didn't Understand" (p. 46); "In Sparta" (p. 47); "A Princeling from West Libya" (p. 48); "The Same Space" (p. 49); "He Asked about the Quality" (pp. 50-51); "They Should Have Seen to It" (pp. 52-53); "In the Suburbs of Antioch" (pp. 54-55).

The Amin is not on the title page.

full_text:
Constantine Cavafy. _Selected Poems_. Translated with an introduction by Avi Sharon. London; New York: Penguin Books, 2008. xxix, 220 p.

Includes: Chronology (pp. xiii-xiv); Introduction (pp. xv-xxiii); Further Reading (pp. xxiv-xxv); Translator's Note (pp. xxvi-xxix). The translations are given in four parts: Part I. Poems 1897-1904; Part II. Poems 1905-1919; Part III. Poems 1916-1918; Part IV. Poems 1919-1933. Notes (pp. 185-209); Index of Titles (pp. 211-215); Index of First Lines (pp. 216-220).

ISBN 0141185619 pbk.; 978-0-141-18561-3 pbk.

[Although entitled _Selected Poems_ the book gives the usual canon of 154 poems.]

full_text:
[C.P. Cavafy]. _Selected Poems of C.P. Cavafy_. Translated by Desmond O'Grady. Dublin: Dedalus; Chester Springs, PA: Distributed in the U.S.A. and Canada by Dufour Editions, 1998. 48 p.

ISBN 1 901233 26 X; 9781901233261

Contains: Introduction (pp. 7-8). Thirty-three poems: "Candles (p. 13); "Footsteps" (p. 14); "Ithaka" (pp. 15-17); "Voices" (p. 18); "This City" (p. 19); "Ionian" (p. 20); "Windows" (p. 21); "Expecting the Barbarians" (pp. 22-23); "One of Their Gods" (p. 24); "Thermopylae" (p. 25); "Come Back" (p. 26); "I Went" (p. 27); "He Swears" (p. 28). "One Night" (p. 29); "The Tobacco Shop" (p. 30); "Days of 1903" (p. 31); "So Much Beauty" (p. 32); "Rites of Passage" (p. 33); "Long Ago" (p. 34); "At the Café Door" (p. 35); "Nero's Deadline" (p. 36); "One Evening" (p. 37); "Remember, Body" (p. 38); "In a Town of Osroini" (p. 39); "Grey" (p. 40); "The Month of Athyr" (p. 41); "Tomb of Iasis" (p. 42); "That House" (p. 43); "Since Nine O'Clock" (p. 44); "At Rest in Verse" (p. 45); "On Board Ship" (p. 46); "Those Who Fought" (p. 47); "He Came to Read" (p. 48).

[The same poems as in O'Grady's publication of 1993 (_Alternative Manners: Poems of C.P. Cavafy_) {4.336].

full_text:
C. P. Cavafy. _Selected Prose Works_. Translated and Annotated by Peter Jeffreys. Writers on Writing. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 2010. xix, 163 p.

ISBN 9780472070954 (cloth); 9780472050956 (pbk.)

Contains: Preface by Dimitris Tziovas (pp. xi-xii); Translator's Introduction (pp. xiii-xix). The following prose texts:

I. Essays: "1. What I Remember of My Essay on Christopulus" (pp. 3-4); "2. Fragment on Lycanthropy" (pp. 5-9); "3. Fragment on Woman and the Ancients" (p. 10); "4. Fragment on Beliefs concerning the Soul" (p. 11); "4. Persian Manners" (pp. 12-13); "6. Masks" (p. 14); "7. Misplaced Tenderness" (pp. 15-16); "8. Coral from a Mythological Perspective" (pp. 17-18); "9. Romaic Folk-lore of Enchanted Animals" (pp. 19-20); "10. Give Back the Elgin Marbles" (pp. 21-22); "11. An Update on the Elgin Marbles" (pp. 23-26); "12. Shakespeare on Life" (pp. 27-30); "13. Professor Blackie on the Modern Greek Language" (pp. 31-35); "14. The Byzantine Poets" (pp. 36-40); "14. Our Museum" (pp. 41-42); "16. Lamia" (pp. 43-53); "17. The Cypriot Question" (pp. 54-57); "18. Traces of Greek Thought in Shakespeare" (pp. 58-59); "19. Greek Scholars in Roman Houses" (pp. 60-65); "20. A Page of Trojan History" (pp. 66-67); "21. On the Intellectual Affinity of Egypt and the West" (pp. 68-69).

II. Fiction and Creative Writing: "22. A Night Out in Kalinderi" (pp. 73-76); "23. The Mountain" (pp. 77-79); "24. Garments" (p. 80); "24. The Pleasure Brigade"(p. 81); "26. Musings of an Aging Artist" (pp. 82-83); "27. The Ships" (pp. 84-85); "28. In Broad Daylight" (pp. 86-93).

III. Literary Reflections: "29. On Browning" (pp. 97-102); "30 The Last Days of Odysseus" (pp. 103-111); "31. A Few Pages on the Sophists" (pp. 112-115); "32. Philosophical Scrutiny: Part One" (pp. 116-119); "33. On _The Chronicle of Morea_" (pp. 120-122); "34. Independence" (pp. 123-124).

IV. Miscellaneous: "34. On Saint Symeon the Stylite" (p. 127); "36. Greeks and Not Romans" (p. 128); "37. Twenty-Seven Notes on Poetics and Ethics" (pp. 129-139); "38. A Note on Obsolete Words" (p. 140); "39. For a Student Anthology of Demotic Songs" (pp. 141-142); "40. On the Poet C.P. Cavafy" (p. 143).

Translator's Notes (pp. 145-163).

full_text:
[Constantine Cavafy]. _A Tribute to Cavafy: A Selection of Poems with Photogravures by Duane Michals and Translations by Edmund Keeley & Philip Sherrard._ [New York]: The Limited Editions Club, 2003. Bilingual edition., [31] p., [5] leaves of [interspersed] plates. Oversize.

ISBN ---

"Three hundred copies [...] were designed and printed by Dan Carr & Julia Ferrari on Arches vellum with Monotype Dante and Gill Sans Light Greek cast and hand set at Golgonooza Letter Foundry & Press in Ashuelot, New Hampshire. The photogravures [by Duane Michals] were made and hand printed by Jon Goodman in Florence, Ma. Bound by Carol Joyce at Academy Bindery."

Includes a four-page insert: "A Tribute to Cavafy: Six Poems Translated into English Verse by Edmund Keeley & Philip Sherrard. With Photogravures by Duana Michals" (The Limited Editions Club, No. 593, Series 62, Volume 2 (November 2003)). [The main book]: "Days of 1903" (Μέρες του 1903); "In the Month of Athyr" (Εν τω μηνί ΑΘΥΡ); "The God Abandons Antony" (Απολείπειν ο θεός Αντώνιον); "Voices" (Φωνές); "Ithaka" (Ιθάκη); "Prayer" (Δέησις); Duane Michals, Afterword "Cavafy's Reveries" .

'Copy 40' in The Graphic Arts Collection, Rare Books and Special Collections, Princeton University Library.

full_text:
[C.P. Cavafy]. _"... what these Ithakas mean." Readings in Cavafy / «... η Ιθάκες τί σημαίνουν». Αναγνώσεις στον Καβάφη_. Editors: Artemis Leontis, Lauren E. Talalay and Keith Taylor. Αθήνα: Ελληνικό Λογοτεχνικό και Ιστορικό Αρχείο / Athens: Hellenic Literary and Historical Archive, 2002. 148 p.

ISBN 960-201-154-8; 9789602011546

Contains: Artemis Leontis, Laured E. Talalay, and Keith Taylor: Πρόλογος / Preface (pp. 9-15); Εισαγωγή / Introduction (pp. 17-25); Η ζωή του Καβάφη / Cavafy's Life (pp. 27-41).

Poems + comments: "Walls" (p. 43); "The Horses of Achilles" (p. 44), comments by Laurence Goldstein (p. 45); "The Funeral of Sarpedon" (pp. 46-47); "The First Step" (p. 48), comments by Charles Baxter (p. 49); "A Heart's Epic" [William W. Reader and Keith Taylor, trs.] (p. 50), by Alexandra Charitatou (p. 51); "Growing in Spirit" (p. 52), comments by Vassilis Lambropoulos (p. 53); "Voices" (p. 54), comments by Nicholas Howe (p. 55), Thomas Lynch (p. 56), and Eleni Sikelianos (p. 57); "Waiting for the Barbarians" (pp. 58-59), comments by William V. Spanos (p. 60), Maurice Tempelsman (p. 61), Nanos Valaoritis (p. 62), and Anne Waldman (p. 63); "Poseidonians" (p. 64), comments by David Konstan (p. 65); "The Footsteps" (p. 66); "The Retinue of Dionysos" (p. 67); "Hidden Things" [John Chioles, tr.] (p. 68), comments by John Chioles (p. 69); "The City" (p. 70), Comments by Rita Dove (p. 71), Peter Green (p. 72), Rachel Hadas (p. 73) and Peter Murphy (p. 74); "Philhellene" (p. 75); "The God Abandons Antony" (p. 76), comments by Edward Hirsch (p. 77), Robert Kelly (p. 78), and Ruth Scodel (p. 79); "Ithaka" (p. 80), comments by Nicholas Samaras (pp. 81-82) and Richard Tillinghast (pp. 83-84); "In Church" (p. 85); "Ionic" (p. 86), comments by Tom Andrews (p. 87) and Edmund Keeley (p. 88); "For the Shop" (p. 89); "Tomb of the Grammarian Lysias" (p. 90), comments by Dimitris Dimiroulis (p. 91) [tr. by Artemis Leontis, Keith Taylor, and Vassilis Lambropoulos]; "Long Ago" (p. 92), comments by Nicholas Delbanco (p. 93) and Lauren E. Talalay (p. 94); "Tomb of Evrion" (p. 95); "Going Back Home from Greece" (p. 96), comments by Artemis Leontis (p. 97); "Painted" [Alexander Nehamas, tr.] (p. 98), comments by Alexander Nehamas (p. 99); "Simeon" (p. 100), comments by Dimitris Kalokyris (pp. 101-102); "Manuel Komninos" (p. 103); "I've Looked So Much ..." (p. 104); "For Ammonis, Who Died at 29. in 610" (p. 105); "Kaisarion" (p. 106), comments by Keith Taylor (p. 107); "One of Their Gods" (p. 108); "In the Month of Athyr" (p. 109); "The Afternoon Sun" [James Merrill, tr.] (p. 110), comments by David M. Halperin (pp. 111-112); "Of the Jews (A.D. 50)" (p. 113); "Dareios" (p. 114), comments by Yiorgos Chouliaras (p. 115), Dick Davis (p. 116), and Stathis Gourgouris (p. 117); "Melancholy of Jason Kleander, Poet in Kommagini, A.D. 595" (p. 118); "He Had Come There to Read" (p. 119); "A Byzantine Nobleman in Exile Composing Verses" (p. 120), comments by Mimis Souliotis [tr. by Helen Stavrou] (p. 121); "Those Who Fought for the Achaian League" (p. 122), comments by John P. Anton (p. 123); "In Alexandria, 31 B.C." (p. 124), comments by Peter Bien (pp. 125-127); "In the Same Space" (p. 128), comments by Mark Jarman (p. 129); "Myris: Alexandria, A.D. 340" (pp. 130-131), comments by Gregory Jusdanis (p. 132); "Of Colored Glass"; "Following the Recipe of Ancient Greco-Syrian Magicians" (p. 134), comments by Peter Jeffreys (p. 135); "In the Year 200 B.C." (p. 136), comments by Paul Cartledge (p. 137); "Kleitos' Illness" (p. 138).

In all cases where the names of translators are not given translators are Edmund Keeley & Philip Sherrard.

full_text:
[C. P. Cavafy.] "After Cavafy". Poems of Cavafy rewritten in new versions (in English) by John Ash in Part 2 of his collection _In the Wake of the Day_ (Manchester, [UK]: Carcanet Press Limited, 2010): 45-60.

The poems, and their Cavafian models (identified by the present editors), are the following: "Without Memorial" (no model located) (p. 45); "Fever of Kleitos", 1. -- «Η αρρὠστια του Κλείτου» (p. 46), "Fever of Kleitos", 2. (no model located) (p. 47); "The Battle of Magnesia", 1 "A Maker of Mixing Bowls" – «Τεχνουργός κρατήρων» (p. 48), "The Battle of Magnesia", 2. "Sorrow of Macedon" – «Η μάχη της Μαγνησίας» (p. 49); "Antiochus Epiphanes" -- «Προς τον Αντίοχον Επιφανή» (p. 50); "The Gods in Their Wisdom" – «Ας φρόντιζαν» (pp. 51-52); "In Ösroene" – «Εν πόλει της Οσροήνης» (p. 53); "Disillusionment of Demetrius Soter" – «Δημητρίου Σωτήρος (162-150 π.Χ.)» (pp. 54-55); "The Triumph of John Katakouzenos", 1. "A Bishop's Assurances" – «Ο Ιωάννης Κατακουζηνός υπερισχύει» (p. 56), "The Triumph of John Katakouzenos", 2. "Of Coloured Glass" – «Από υαλί χρωματιστό» (p. 57); "Exiles" – «Φυγάδες» (p. 58); "A Byzantine Nobleman Writing in Exile" – «Βυζαντινός άρχων, εξόριστος, στιχουργών» (p. 59); "In a Syrian Harbour" – «Εις το επίνειον» (p. 60).

full_text:
[C.P. Cavafy]. "The Early C.P. Cavafy". Translated by John Cavafy; Edmund Keeley, intro. _St. Andrews Review_ 3.1 (Fall and Winter 1974): 37-47. <Poems>

Intrtoduction (pp. 37-39). The translations are selected from two unpublished typescripts dated 1916 and 1917. They include the poems: "Interruption" (p. 39); "'Che Fece...Il Gran Rifiuto'" (pp. 39-41); "The Horses of Achilles"; "'This is He'" (p. 41); "Walls"; "The Glory of the Ptolemies"; "The Place" (p. 43); "Philhellene"; "Come Again" (p. 45); "Of the Workshop" (pp. 45-46); "Sea of the Morning"; "In a Town of Osrhoene" (p. 46); "At the Cafe Door" (pp. 46-47); "The Aemilian, Son of Monaes, of Alexandria. 628-655 A.D." (p. 47).

(p. 47).

full_text:
[C.P. Cavafy]. "Sexton Dikter".Translated by Evangelos Sachperoglou. In _Läsa Kavafis. Valda Dikter_. Stockholm: Ersatz, 2007: 62-76.

"Desires" (p. 62); "Waiting for the Barbarians" (pp. 63-64); "Ithaca" (p. 65); "Very Seldom" (p. 66); "The Poet and the Muse" (p. 67); "Good and Bad Weather" (p. 68); "Gray" (p. 69); "In the Evening" (p. 70); "Come Back" (p. 71); "Their Origin" (p. 72); "Since Nine O'Clock" (p. 73); "The City" (p. 74); "One Night" (p. 75); "Sensual Delight" (p. 76).

These 14 poems are preceded by the 16 poems of which the title speaks ("Sexton Dikter"), in the original Greek text and in a Swedish translation by Rea Mellberg and Magnus William-Olsson (pp. 15-61). The two "extra" Greek-Swedish poems are "Φυγάδες / I exil" (pp. 58-59) and "Μισή ώρα / Halvtimme" (pp. 60-61).

Contains:

*Modern Greek First Online Roundtable: Cavafy*

Savidis, Manuel. "Cavafy through the Looking-Glass" (Febr. 2005).

"Manuel Savidis' position paper on the state of Cavafy research, "Cavafy Through the Looking-Glass," which we solicited and posted on our website last year, inspired a variety of responses and provoked discussion:"

Dracopoulos, Anthony. "On Reading Cavafy: The Man or the Poetry" (Febr. 2006).

Jeffreys, Peter. "Cavafian Catoptromancy: A Response to Mr. Savidis" (Febr. 2006).

Karalis, Vrasidas. "The Transcultural and the Individual in Cavafy: A Brief Response" Febr. 2006).

Papanikolaou, Dimitris. "From the Darkrooms of Philology" (Febr. 2006).

Savidis, Manuel. "Some Notes on the Cavafy Forum" (March 2006).

**2006**

Hartsock, Katie. "The Cavafy Sense, the Cavafy Sensuality" (October 2006).

Jusdanis, Gregory. "Cavafy's Anomaly" (September 2006).

**2008**

Economou, George. "Dropping Anchor at Ithaca" (October 2008).

Translations of and comments on Cavafy's "Half an Hour", "Craftsman of Wine Bowls", "According to the Recipes of Ancient Greco-Syrian Magicians".

Gourgouris, Stathis. "Poiein―Political Infinitive" (2008).

Hopkins, Curt. "Denying Julian: Cavafy's Julian Poems" (December 2008).

O'Connell, Richard. "Parallel Texts" (September 2008).

**2009**

Boletsi, Maria. "The Travels of a Literary Topos: C. P. Cavafy's 'Waiting for the Barbarians' and Its Visual Restagings" (June 2009).

*The Typography of Desire*

Final Papers from Professor Karen Van Dyck's course on Cavafy at Columbia University (June 2009):

Van Dyck Karen, Karen Emmerich, and James Nikopoulos, "Introductory Notes".

Mastor, Andriana. "Offbeat Echolalia: Merrill's Lessons for the Translator of Cavafy's Poetry".

Nikopoulos, James. "Cavafy's Greek (in Translation)".

Radisoglou, Alexis. "Ethics from a Slight Angle: Cavafy's Poetry as Historiographic Metafiction".

Smith, Lytton Jackson. "The Translation of Punctuation: An Analysis of Three Poems by C. P. Cavafy".

Focusing in particular on three poems connected with the sea: "The City", "In the Harbour Town", and "On the Italian Shore".

Stergiopoulou, Katerina. "Saving the Lacedaimonians: Towards a Translation of Cavafy's Languages".

Wade, Elizabeth Wildman. "Beyond Biography: Cavafy's Homoeroticism in Translation".

**2010**

Frier, Bruce W. "Making History Personal: Constantine Cavafy and the Rise of Rome" (April 2010).

McKinsey, Martin. "Where Are the Greeks? Revisiting Cavafy's 'Philhellene'" (February 2010).

Michelakis, Pantelis. "Performances and Epitaphs in C.P. Cavafy's 'Young Men of Sidon, A.D. 400'" (October 2010).

Crispin, Mat <sic>. _Cavafy: Anatomy of a Soul_. Kidderminster, Worcestershire, UK: Crescent Moon Publishing, 1993. 99 p. <Essays> Cover illustration by Cassidy Hughes.

ISBN 1-871846-22-6

On the 'copyright' page the first name of the author is spelled "Matt".

Contents: Poreword (pp. 1-3); "Condemned Years" (pp. 4-14); "Beyond the Symbols" (pp. 15-22); "Eros" (pp. 23-35): 'Daydream fantasies' (pp. 26-29), 'Sensual delight' (pp. 29-32), 'Graves' (pp. 33-35); "The Healing Poetry" (pp. 36-39); "Interlude of Fear" (pp. 40-49); "Satire" (pp. 50-53); "Miniature Portraits" (pp. 54-70): 'Poets' (pp. 55-64), 'Rulers & Ruled' (pp. 64-70); "The Never-Ending War" (pp. 71-99): ''In part a Christian …'' (pp. 71-88), 'The Julian entr'acte' (pp. 88-92), ''… and in part a pagan'' (pp. 92-99), 'Cleaving of Soul' (p. 99).

Note: the book is bound so that the odd pages are on the left and the even pages on the right.

full_text:
[Jeffreys, Peter]. _The Forster–Cavafy Letters. Friends at a Slight Angle_. Edited and annotated by Peter Jeffreys. Cairo, Egypt; New York, NY: American University in Cairo Press, 2009. xvii, 191 p.

ISBN: 9774162579; 978 977 416 257 2

The volume includes all extant letters, the earliest Cavafy translations by George Valassopoulos (incorporating Cavafy's own authorial emendations), edited by Katerina Ghika and Peter Jeffreys, and further poems by E.M. Forster, archival photographs, and related letters. The foreword is of Manuel Savidis.

full_text:
Kolaitis, Memas.] _Cavafy as I Knew Him: With 96 Annotated Translations of His Poems, and a Translation of_ The Golden Verses _of Pythagoras_ by Memas Kolaitis. Santa Barbara, CA: © Memas Kolaitis, 1980. 327 (one-sided) leaves.\* Bilingual edition. Bound typescript.

ISBN ---

Contains: "Two Self-inflicted Sketches" [illustration] (p. [v]); 'Cavafy as I Knew Him' [fourteen chapters on Cavafy]: I. "My Reasons for this Work" (pp. 1-5); II. "'Mixed Idiom' and Cavafy" (pp. 6-28); III. "Cavafy's Alexandria" (pp. 29-34); IV. "My Association with Cavafy" (pp. 35-43); V. "On Cavafy and 'Society'" (pp. 44-48); VI: "Malanos as 'Critic and Psychographer'" (pp. 49-57); VII. "'Cavafian Self-Comments'" (pp. 58-63); VIII. "Cavafy's Middle Name" (pp. 64-66); IX. "Cavafy's Rue Lepsius" (pp. 67-68); X. "Cavafy's 'Hellenicity'" (pp. 69-80); XI. "Cavafy and Translations" (pp. 81-82); XII. "Cavafy's Religious Feelings" (pp. 83-85); XIII. "Cavafy's Homosexuality" (pp. 86-89); XIV. "Cavafy as a Poet" (pp. 90-94).

'Memas Kolaitis's annotated translations of 96 poems by C. P. Cavafy' (pp. 95-270) [Title page† and Translator's Note precede p. 95, on two unnumbered pages]: "Ionic" (p. 95); "The City" (pp. 96-97); "Ithaca" (p. 98-101)\*; "The Ship's" (pp. 102-104)\*; "Che fece … il gran rifiuto" (p. 105); "Walls" (pp. 106-108); "Voices" (p. 109); "Anna Dalassena" (pp. 110-111); "Anna Comnena" (pp. 112-113); "Candles" (pp. 114-115); "In the Environs of Antioch" (pp. 116-120); "The Souls of Ancient Men" (p. 121); "Philhellene" (pp. 122-124); "Addition" (p. 125); "Aristobulus" (pp. 126-128); "Return" (p. 129); "Awaiting the Barbarians" (pp. 130-132); "As Best as You Can" (p. 133); "In a Town of Osrhoene" (pp. 134-135); "Trojans" (pp. 136-137); "In 200 B.C." (pp. 138-141); "Theodotus" (pp. 142-143); "Hazardous Ventures" (pp. 144-148); "In This Very Space" (p. 149); "Lysias the Grammarian's Tomb" (pp. 150-152); "The Morning Sea" (p. 153); "The Satrapy" (pp. 154-156); "But Rarely" (p. 157); "Of the Hebrews (50 A.D.)" (pp. 158-159); "Melancholy of Jason of Cleander, a Poet in Commagene, 595 A.D." (pp. 160-161); "The Glory of the Ptolemies" (pp. 162-163); "Alexandrian Kings" (pp. 164-166); "Favor of Alexander Balas" (p. 167); "For Ammon, Who Died at 29, in 610" (pp. 168-169); "In a Great Greek Colony, 200 B.C." (pp. 170-172); "In Church" (p. 173); "The End of Antony" (pp. 174-175); "From Recipes of Ancient Graeco-Syrian Magi" (pp. 176-177); "An Evening" (pp. 178-179); "The God Forsaking Antony" (pp. 180-181); "Apollonius of Tyana in Rhodes" (p. 182); "Not Discerned" (p. 183); "Herodes Atticus" (pp. 184-185); "Through Pleasure" (p. 186); "Awareness of Love" (p. 187); "Of the School of the Renowned Philosopher" (pp. 188-190); "Priest of the Serapeum" (p. 191); "Ides of March" (pp. 192-193); "They Could Have Had a Care" (pp. 194-196); "Days of 1903" (p. 197); "Demaratus" (pp. 198-200); "Ignatius' Tomb" (p. 201); "If Indeed Deceased" (pp. 202-204); "Who Fought for the Achaean League" (p. 205); "Eurion's Tomb" (pp. 206-207); "Alexander Yannai, and Alexandra" (pp. 208-210); "He Vows" (p. 211); "Crossing Over" (p. 212); "When Aroused" (p. 213); "Covertly" (pp. 214-215); "I Went" (p. 216); "The Nearby Table" (p. 217); "So Long Intently I Beheld" (p. 218); "Conclusively" (p. 219); "Byzantine Archon, Exiled, Versifying" (pp. 220-221); "Understanding" (pp. 222-223); "Days of 1908" (pp. 224-226); "The Bank of Futureness" (p. 227); "Tombstone Inscription for Antiochus, a King of Commagene" (pp. 228-229); "To Art I Offered" (pp. 230-231); "The Shop's" (pp. 232-233); "One of Their Gods" (pp. 234-235); "Far Back" (p. 236); "Their Beginning" (p. 237); "Theophilus Palaeologus" (p. 238); "The Windows" (p. 239); "Monotony" (p. 240); "Anciently Greek" (p. 241); "Since Nine –" (pp. 242-243); "Poseidonians" (pp. 244-245); "Of Colored Glass" (pp. 246-247); "Thermopylae" (pp. 248-249); "King Demetrius" (pp. 250-251); "To Live and Stay" (pp. 252-253); "Grey" (p. 254); "Theater of Sidon (400 A.D.)" (p. 255); "Pictorially" (p. 256); "Chandelier" (p. 257); "One Night" (p. 258); "Aemilianus Monai, Alexandrian 628-655 B.C." [sic]  A.D. (p. 259); "A Leader out of Western Libya" (pp. 260-261); "The First Step" (pp. 262-263); "Trepidation" (pp. 264-265); "The Hereafter" (p. 270).

'Memas Kolaitis's Translation of the _Golden Verses of Pythagoras'_ (pp. 271-275).

Index of Translations (pp. 278-280); Chronological Index of Poems by C. P. Cavafy (pp. 280-289); Index of Annotations (pp. 290-305); Index of Names (pp. 305-310); Topical Index (pp. 310-327).

\*Note: This item has been located only in the Library of Congress (PA 5610 .K2 Z735), from which copy pp. 99-102 are missing. The four missing pages may be supplied through reference to _Cavafy as I Knew Him, with 12 Annotated Translations of His Poems and a Translation of The Golden Verses of Pythagoras by Memas Kolaitis_ (entry **4.612)**, pp. 95-98.

†On the title page of the annotated translations of poems by C. P. Cavafy, a note: "Translations are not arranged either "thematically" or "chronologically", since they were subject only to translator's mood and convenience."

All the poems are printed in Greek and English; the annotations to the poems and the indexes contain words and phrases in Greek.

Mihopoulos, Effie, Joseph Pentheroudakis, Douglas Macdonald, eds. _Konstantinos Kabaphes. Two Hands News_ (Chicago) 11 (Sept. 1977).

ISBN ---

Pamphlet of four leaves, published by the bookstore _Two Hands_. It contains: "For Cavafy"; "A Day in Alexandria"; "A Selection of Cavafy's Poems": "The Polis"; "Che fece ... il grand refiuto"; "Special Reading"; "A Brief Sketch of the Life and Work"; "The Love Poems"; "On Translating Cavafy"; "English Translations of Cavafy Poems". There is also an inserted loose leaf with a translation into English of the poem Η πόλις, translated by the three editors.

full_text:
_Ithaca_ 11 (Sept.-Oct. 2001): _C.P. Cavafy_. Special Issue.

Contains: _C.P. Cavafy and His International Recognition_: Dimitris Daskalopoulos, "Foreign Authors on C.P. Cavafy" (pp. 12-14); E.M. Forster, "The Poetry of C.P. Cavafy" (pp. 15-16); F.T. Marinetti, "Cavafy, the Greek-Egyptian Poet" (from the Greek translation by Lucia Marcheselli) (pp. 17-18); Rex Warner, "The Poems of C.P. Cavafy" (pp. 19-21); Guiseppe Ungaretti, "Cavafy, the Last Alexandrian" (from the Greek translation by P. Yerenis) (p. 22); Margueritte Yourcenar, "A Critical Presentation of C.P. Cavafy" (from the Greek translation by G.P. Savvidis) (pp. 23-24); Michel Déon, "Balcony in Spetses" (from the Greek translation by Andreas V. Vachliotis) (p. 25); W.H. Auden, "The Complete Poems of Cavafy" (pp. 26-27); Eugenio Montale, "A Greek Poet" (pp. 28-30); Stephen Spender, "Cavafy: The Historic and Erotic" (pp. 31-32); Joseph Brodsky, "Pendulum's Song" (pp. 33-24).

_The_ '_Globalization' of Cavafy_. Selection of Poets Included in the Anthology of Nassos Vayenas: Nassos Vayenas, "In the Manner of C.P. Cavafy". Brissenden, Bertolt Brecht, Joachim Sartorius, Guy Goffette, Maria Luisa Spaziani, Eugenio Montale, Joan Margarit, Jyan Gustavo Cobo Borda, José Maria Alvarez, C.O. Jellema, Miroslav Holub, Virgil Mazilescu, Blaga Dimitrova, Ivan Gadjanski, Moikom Zequo (pp. 39-59); "Selected Translations" (pp. 60-62).

full_text:
_Journal of the Hellenic Diaspora_ 10.1-2 (Spring-Summer 1983). Special Double Issue: C.P. Cavafy. Margaret Alexiou, guest ed. and intro. New York: Pella Publishing Co.

Includes: Margaret Alexiou, "Introduction" (pp. 7-9); Alexander Kitroeff, "The Alexandria We Have Lost" (pp. 11-21); Roderick Beaton, "The History Man" (pp. 23-44); Margaret Alexiou, "Eroticism and Poetry" (pp. 45-65); S.D. Kapsalis, "'Privileged Moments': Cavafy's Autobiographical Inventions" (pp. 67-88); Dimitris Dimiroulis, "Cavafy's Imminent Threat: Still 'Waiting for the Barbarians'" (pp. 89-103); Helen Catsaouni, "Cavafy and the Theatrical Representation of History" (pp. 105-116); Peter Bien, "Cavafy's Three-Phase Development into Detachment" (pp. 117-136); Gregory Jusdanis, "The Modes of Reading; Or Why Interpret?
